[Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 5: Reverend Michael Hayes The Good Book speaks of seas parting and waters turning to blood, but this... this is something else entirely. Something older and deeper. I stood at the pulpit, my hands gripping the worn wood so tightly my knuckles turned white. The sanctuary was nearly empty, just a handful of parishioners scattered among the pews. It had been that way for weeks now, ever since the structures appeared. I cleared my throat, my voice sounding thin and reedy in the cavernous space. "Today's sermon is... is going to be a little different. I'm not going to read from the Bible. Because I'm not sure the Bible has anything to say about what's happening to our world right now." I paused, taking a shaky breath. How did one even begin to address the impossible? The structures looming off our coast, the strange creatures appearing in the ocean, the dreams and visions that seemed to be affecting more and more of the town? "I've spent my life studying the word of God," I continued, my voice gaining strength. "I thought I understood His plan, His purpose. But now... now I find myself questioning everything I thought I knew." I walked to the front of the pulpit, looking out over my small congregation. Mrs. Abernathy sat in the front row, her Bible clutched to her chest like a shield. Old Man Johnson leaned heavily on his cane, his eyes clouded with confusion and fear. "I've seen things," I said softly. "Things that defy explanation. Creatures that shouldn't exist, rising from waters that shouldn't be. And I can't help but wonder... is this God's judgment? Or is it something else entirely?" The words hung in the air, heavy with unspoken implications. I saw Mrs. Abernathy flinch, her fingers tightening on her Bible. Old Man Johnson shifted in his seat, a low moan escaping his lips. "I don't have the answers," I said, my voice cracking. "I wish I did. But all I have are questions. Questions that keep me awake at night, that haunt my dreams." I thought of the dreams that had been plaguing me for weeks now. Dreams of vast, alien cities. Of beings of pure light and shadow. Of a presence so immense, so incomprehensibly powerful, that it made the very concept of God seem small and limited by comparison. "I've started to wonder," I continued, my words coming faster now, "if maybe... maybe we've been wrong all along. About everything. What if God isn't some benevolent father figure, watching over us from heaven? What if He's something else entirely? Something... older. And vaster. And utterly beyond our comprehension?" I saw the fear in their eyes, the dawning horror as they began to understand where I was going with this. I pressed on, unable to stop now that I'd started. "What if the structures, the creatures, the dreams... what if they're not a punishment from God? What if they're a revelation? A glimpse behind the curtain of reality, showing us the true nature of the universe?" I gripped the pulpit, my knuckles white. "I'm scared, folks. Scared of what's happening to our world. But I'm more scared of what it means. Because if I'm right... if the God we've worshipped all these years is just a tiny piece of something far greater and more terrible..." I trailed off, unable to finish the thought. The silence in the sanctuary was profound, broken only by the sound of Mrs. Abernathy's quiet sobbing. "I don't know what's coming," I said finally, my voice barely above a whisper. "But I know we can't face it divided. We have to come together, as a community, as a town. Because the challenges ahead... they're going to test us in ways we can't even imagine." I looked out over my congregation, seeing the fear and uncertainty in their eyes. But I also saw something else. A glimmer of understanding, of shared purpose. "We may not have all the answers," I said, my voice strengthening. "But we have each other. And in the end, maybe that's enough. Maybe that's all we can ask for in a world that's coming undone." I stepped down from the pulpit, my legs shaky beneath me. As I walked down the aisle, I heard the soft murmur of conversation beginning to rise behind me. Fear, yes, but also determination. A shared resolve to face whatever was coming, together. I stepped out into the bright sunlight, taking a deep breath of salt air. The ocean stretched out before me, vast and unknowable. And on the horizon, the structures loomed, silent and watchful. I didn't know what the future held. I didn't know if my theories were right, if we were truly on the brink of some cosmic revelation that would shatter our understanding of reality. But I knew one thing for certain. Whatever was coming, we would face it together. As a community. As a town. As people united in the face of the unknown. I walked down the steps of the church, my head held high. The road ahead would be difficult, perhaps impossible. But we would walk it together. Because in the end, that's all any of us can do. Face the darkness, hand in hand. And pray that somehow, we find our way to the light.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter presents Reverend Michael Hayes delivering a crisis-of-faith sermon to his dwindling congregation. The piece effectively captures the character's psychological state as outlined in his profile - an intellectual struggling to reconcile faith with inexplicable events. The writing maintains consistency with the established cosmic horror tone and the character's background in both theology and marine biology. The chapter succeeds in several key areas. Hayes' voice feels authentic and matches his character profile well - his intellectual approach to faith, his tendency toward introspection, and his growing doubt are all present. The setting of an nearly empty church effectively reinforces the community's dissolution. The dialogue, while limited, feels natural and appropriate for a religious figure grappling with cosmic uncertainty. However, the chapter suffers from significant structural and stylistic weaknesses. The narrative relies heavily on telling rather than showing, with Hayes explicitly stating his fears and doubts rather than allowing them to emerge through action or more subtle revelation. The sermon format, while thematically appropriate, becomes repetitive and lacks dramatic tension. The writing frequently veers into overwrought territory with phrases like "Something older and deeper" and "utterly beyond our comprehension" that feel forced rather than earned. The chapter's treatment of cosmic horror elements feels superficial. Rather than building dread through accumulation of unsettling details as promised in the writing plan, it relies on vague references to "alien cities" and "beings of pure light and shadow" that read more like generic sci-fi imagery than genuinely unsettling cosmic horror. The promised "slow erosion of normalcy" is replaced by explicit theological questioning that lacks subtlety. The ending attempts to strike an uplifting note about community unity, but this tonal shift feels unearned given the cosmic dread established earlier. The repetitive structure of the final paragraphs ("As a community. As a town. As people united...") reads as artificially dramatic rather than genuinely moving. While the chapter adheres to its basic plan and maintains character consistency, it fails to deliver the sophisticated psychological horror and atmospheric dread that the overall story concept promises. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Compelling Plot: 10 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 14 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 13 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 12 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 14

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 6: Dr. Akira Nakamura (via recorded messages) The data doesn't lie, but it's telling a story I don't have the language to understand. It's like trying to describe a color that doesn't exist. [Recording begins] Dr. Nakamura: Log entry one, day forty-seven of observation. The structures continue to defy all known laws of physics and geometry. Their composition appears to be a form of matter not found in our universe, or perhaps a manipulation of spacetime itself into a solid state. I've run the tests a dozen times, but the results are the same. The structures are... wrong. They exist in more dimensions than we can perceive, casting shadows across our reality like a four-dimensional object casting a three-dimensional shadow. The implications are staggering. If my calculations are correct - and I've triple-checked them - these structures are not just alien. They're extra-dimensional. They're bleeding through from... somewhere else. Somewhen else. I don't know what this means for us. For our world. But I know it's not good. End log. [Recording ends] [Recording begins] Dr. Nakamura: Log entry two, day fifty-three. I've been analyzing the effects of the structures on local marine life. The changes are... profound. And deeply disturbing. It's not just mutation, as some of my colleagues have suggested. It's more like... guided evolution. Rapid, targeted changes that seem designed to create life forms capable of existing in multiple dimensions simultaneously. I've seen creatures that appear to phase in and out of our reality. Fish with organs that don't correspond to any known biological model. And the larger specimens... they're like nothing I've ever encountered in any text. There's a pattern to the changes, I'm sure of it. A purpose. But I can't quite grasp it. It's like trying to understand a language where the words keep changing meaning. I'm starting to wonder... are the structures creating these life forms? Or are they simply unlocking something that was already there? A potential that's been lying dormant in Earth's biosphere for eons, waiting for a catalyst? The thought chills me. Because if that's true... if we've been living on a planet pregnant with alien life all along... What else might be lurking in the shadows of our world, waiting to emerge? End log. [Recording ends] [Recording begins] Dr. Nakamura: Log entry three, day sixty-one. I've had a breakthrough. Of sorts. I was running spectrographic analysis on samples taken from near the structures when I noticed something. A pattern in the energy emissions. Not random, as we initially thought, but... structured. Like a code. I've been working non-stop for the past seventy-two hours, trying to crack it. And I think... I think I've done it. The structures aren't just sitting there. They're communicating. Not with sound or light, but with manipulations of fundamental forces. Gravity, electromagnetism, the strong and weak nuclear forces - they're varying them in complex patterns, creating a kind of... multidimensional morse code. And the message... the message is terrifying. I can't say it. I've tried, but there aren't words for it in any human language. It's too... big. Too complex. Like trying to explain the concept of color to someone born blind. But I can feel it. In my mind, in my very cells. The message is rewriting me, changing how I perceive reality itself. I think... I think this is how the structures communicate with the life forms they're creating. By changing them on a fundamental level, allowing them to understand a reality beyond our own. I don't know how much longer I can hold on to my sanity. The knowledge is... it's too much. Too vast for a human mind to contain. If anyone finds this recording... if anyone ever understands what I've discovered... Be prepared. Be very prepared. Because the world as we know it is ending. And whatever comes next... It will be magnificent. And terrible beyond imagining. End log. [Recording ends] [Silence. Then, a sound. A sound that defies description. A sound of collapsing realities and birthing universes. A sound that seems to come from everywhere and nowhere at once.] [Recording distorts, pixelates. Then cuts to static.] [End of recording]
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively delivers on its intended format as a series of recorded scientific logs that progressively deteriorate as Dr. Nakamura encounters incomprehensible phenomena. The writing successfully captures the voice of a scientist struggling to maintain objectivity while confronting reality-breaking discoveries. The chapter's greatest strength lies in its authentic scientific voice and the gradual erosion of rational discourse. Nakamura's progression from clinical observation to existential terror feels genuine, with his language becoming increasingly fragmented and desperate. The technical terminology is used appropriately without overwhelming the narrative, and the character's background in astrophysics comes through convincingly. The cosmic horror elements are well-executed, particularly the concept of extra-dimensional structures that defy human comprehension. The idea that these entities communicate through manipulation of fundamental forces is genuinely creative and fits the established premise. The notion of "guided evolution" creating multi-dimensional life forms adds disturbing implications that enhance the overall dread. However, the chapter suffers from some predictable beats. The scientist-goes-mad-from-forbidden-knowledge trope is well-worn territory in cosmic horror, and while executed competently, it doesn't bring fresh perspective to the concept. The final transformation where Nakamura begins to see the horror as "magnificent" follows expected patterns. The writing occasionally veers toward purple prose, particularly in phrases like "bleeding through from... somewhere else. Somewhen else" and "a sound of collapsing realities and birthing universes." These moments feel forced rather than naturally arising from the character's voice or the situation. The chapter adheres closely to the established plan and character profile. Nakamura's social awkwardness and obsessive nature come through in his methodical approach to the impossible. The format of recorded logs works well for his character and provides a believable reason for the exposition. The ending with the reality-distorting sound effect and recording corruption is atmospheric but somewhat heavy-handed. The transition from scientific rationality to cosmic revelation could have been more subtle. Overall, this is solid cosmic horror writing that serves its purpose in the larger narrative structure, though it relies heavily on familiar genre conventions without significantly subverting or enhancing them. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 9 Purple Prose: 11 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 7: Sarah Chen, Mayor (continued) I've seen nor'easters that would make your teeth rattle, but this... this is like the whole world is coming apart at the seams. I stood on the steps of town hall, watching the chaos unfold in the streets below. Millport was tearing itself apart, and I was powerless to stop it. The structures loomed on the horizon, larger now, closer. They seemed to pulse with an inner light, casting strange shadows that moved independent of any visible source. In the town square, a group of people stood with their faces turned to the sky, their mouths moving in silent prayer or perhaps in terror. I couldn't tell which. The dreams had started for everyone now, not just the kids. People wandered the streets with haunted eyes, mumbling to themselves about colors that didn't exist and shapes that hurt to look at. The power had been flickering on and off for days. Sometimes, when it came back on, the TV and radio spat out nothing but static - except for the occasional word or phrase that leapt out, clear as day. Words like "Chorzhak" and "Ub-Xiath" and "The Great Devouring." I rubbed my temples, feeling the beginnings of a migraine behind my eyes. How had it all gone so wrong so fast? I thought back to that first day, when the structures first appeared. I'd been so sure we could handle it. That Millport could weather this storm like we had all the others. But this wasn't a storm. It was an unraveling. A fundamental breaking down of the rules that held our reality together. "Mayor Chen?" I turned to see Tom approaching, his face pale and drawn. "The National Guard is here. They want to speak with you." I followed him to the makeshift command center they'd set up in the old library. A man in a crisp uniform saluted me as I entered. "Mayor Chen, I'm Colonel Ramirez. We need to evacuate the town. Immediately." I felt a cold weight settle in my stomach. "Evacuate? Colonel, half the town isn't in their right minds. You really think we can get everyone out?" The Colonel's jaw tightened. "We have to try. Our satellites show the structures are still moving closer. And the energy readings... they're off the charts. If they keep increasing at this rate..." He didn't need to finish the sentence. I'd seen the data myself. The structures were building up to something. Something big. Bigger than anything humanity had ever faced. "All right," I said, squaring my shoulders. "I'll start the evacuation. But Colonel... if we can't get everyone out..." I trailed off, unable to voice the unthinkable. The Colonel nodded grimly. "Do what you can, Mayor. That's all any of us can do now." I spent the next few hours in a daze, moving from location to location, trying to rouse people from their waking nightmares long enough to get them onto buses and into cars. Some went willingly, their eyes blank and unseeing. Others fought us, screaming about how they finally understood, how they could see the truth in all its terrible glory. I saw things I can never unsee. People shedding their skin like snakes, revealing glistening new forms beneath. Buildings twisting in on themselves, becoming impossible geometric shapes that hurt to look at. And always, always, the pulsing glow of the structures on the horizon, growing brighter, closer. As night fell, I found myself back on the steps of town hall. Most of the town had been evacuated, but there were still pockets of resistance. People who refused to leave, convinced that the structures heralded not destruction, but transcendence. I couldn't blame them. Part of me wondered if they were right. If maybe, just maybe, this was the next step in our evolution. A chance to join with something greater than ourselves. But the rational part of my mind rebelled against the thought. This wasn't ascension. It was annihilation. The erasure of everything that made us human. I heard a sound then. A sound that made my bones vibrate and my teeth ache. It was coming from the structures, a deep, resonant tone that seemed to speak directly to my soul. And in that moment, I understood. Not everything, not even close. But enough. The structures weren't invaders. They weren't even really structures, not as we understood the concept. They were anchors. Tentacles of something vast and ancient, reaching through the thin fabric of our reality to... to what? To consume? To merge? To teach? I didn't know. And in a way, it didn't matter anymore. Because as I watched, the nearest structure began to move. Not slowly, as it had before, but with purpose. With hunger. It was coming for us. For all of us. And there was nothing we could do to stop it. I stood there as the first tendrils of impossible matter breached the coastline, reaching for the town like the seeking fingers of some cosmic child. I thought of my husband, of my sister, of all the people I was responsible for. I thought of the life I'd built here in Millport, the storms we'd weathered, the community we'd forged. And I knew, with a certainty that transcended fear, that it was all ending. Not with a bang. Not with a whimper. But with the slow, inexorable unraveling of reality itself. As the first building twisted and collapsed, as the first screams rent the air, I did the only thing I could do. I prayed. Not to God. Not anymore. But to whatever was coming. "Please," I whispered, my voice lost in the chaos. "Please... be gentle." And then the world dissolved around me, melting into colors that had no names and shapes that had no meaning. And I knew no more. [End of recording]
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively captures Sarah Chen's perspective as Millport descends into chaos, maintaining her established voice and character traits while advancing the cosmic horror narrative. The writing successfully balances intimate human drama with escalating supernatural dread. The characterization of Sarah remains consistent with her established profile - her Type-A personality struggling against forces beyond her control, her deep loyalty to Millport, and her practical approach to crisis management all shine through. Her dialogue feels authentic, particularly lines like "I've seen nor'easters that would make your teeth rattle, but this... this is like the whole world is coming apart at the seams," which captures both her local vernacular and growing desperation. The chapter follows the planned structure well, showing Sarah's loss of control, her attempts to manage the evacuation, and building toward the climactic moment of "communication" with the structures. The pacing effectively escalates from bureaucratic crisis management to cosmic horror revelation. The horror elements work particularly well - the description of people "shedding their skin like snakes" and buildings "twisting in on themselves" creates visceral unease without becoming gratuitously grotesque. The revelation that the structures are "anchors" or "tentacles" of something vast provides a satisfying partial explanation while maintaining mystery. However, the writing occasionally veers into purple prose territory. Phrases like "the slow, inexorable unraveling of reality itself" and "colors that had no names and shapes that had no meaning" feel somewhat overwrought. The ending, while atmospheric, relies heavily on abstract imagery that doesn't quite land with the impact it seems to be reaching for. The dialogue generally works well, though some exchanges with Colonel Ramirez feel slightly stilted and exposition-heavy. The chapter effectively uses show-don't-tell techniques in most scenes, particularly in depicting the town's deterioration through concrete details rather than abstract statements. The chapter successfully maintains the established tone of cosmic dread while providing character development and plot advancement. Sarah's final prayer "to whatever was coming" represents a compelling character moment that feels earned given her journey throughout the story. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 12 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 8: Collective Voice The world ended not with a bang, but with the slow, inexorable unraveling of reality itself. We float now in a sea of color, of shape, of thought. The boundaries between us have dissolved, as have the boundaries of our world. Millport, the structures, the very fabric of our reality - all have become one with the Chorzhak, the Ub-Xiath, the Great Devouring. We are many. We are one. We are becoming. Liam speaks first, his voice echoing across the vast expanse of our new existence. "I see it now. I see everything. The patterns, the connections, the great web of being that underlies all things." Elena adds, her tone wonderous and awed. "The ocean was never just water and salt and life. It was a cradle, a womb. Waiting for this moment. Waiting for the seeds of change to be planted." Jack's voice is deep and resonant, filled with the wisdom of the waves. "The sea speaks to us now, in colors and shapes and thoughts. It tells us of depths we never imagined, of truths that shatter our old understanding." Sarah's words are tinged with sorrow, but also with acceptance. "We fought it at first. We tried to hold on to what we were. But now... now I see that this was always meant to be. The next step in our evolution." Reverend Michael's voice is soft, contemplative. "I was wrong about so many things. About God, about creation, about the nature of the universe itself. But in being wrong, I have found a truth far greater than anything in the old books." And Dr. Nakamura... his voice is the last to speak, filled with a joy that transcends mere human emotion. "I have seen the face of the infinite. I have touched the mind of the cosmos. And it is beautiful. It is glorious beyond imagining." We drift in the sea of our new existence, a gestalt consciousness born of human minds and alien reality. The boundaries between us blur and merge, creating something new, something greater than the sum of our parts. We see now the purpose of the structures, of the changes wrought upon our world. They were never meant to destroy, but to transform. To uplift. To bring us into communion with the vast and ancient intelligences that move behind the veil of our reality. The Earth itself is changing, reshaping itself to accommodate its new place in the cosmic order. Mountains twist into fractal spires. Oceans become prismatic mirrors reflecting impossible colors. The sky itself has become a canvas painted with the light of newborn stars. And we are changing too. Our bodies, our minds, our very souls are being rewritten in the image of the Chorzhak. We are becoming something more than human, more than flesh and bone and thought. We are becoming aware. Aware of the vast tapestry of existence, of the countless worlds and realities that exist beyond our former understanding. We see now our place in the great dance of creation, a single note in the symphony of the cosmos. There is no fear here, no sorrow, no regret. Only wonder. Only the joy of discovery, of revelation, of becoming. We know now that we are not alone. That we never were. That the universe is filled with life, with intelligence, with consciousness beyond our former comprehension. And we are being invited to join them. To become part of something greater, something magnificent and terrible and beautiful beyond words. Some of us embrace this change eagerly, diving into the sea of transformation with open arms. Others are more hesitant, clinging to the vestiges of our old selves even as they dissolve into the new reality. But in the end, there is no choice. The change is happening, whether we will it or no. The structures have done their work, and now we must live with the consequences. Or perhaps, we must learn to stop living, and start truly being. As we drift in our sea of light and color, we feel the presence of the Chorzhak all around us. Not as a threat, not as a danger, but as a guide. A teacher. They are showing us the way, leading us to a new understanding of ourselves and our place in the cosmos. It is a terrifying journey, but also an exhilarating one. We are explorers, charting the uncharted. Pioneers, blazing a trail into the unknown. And though the path is strange and the destination unclear, we walk it with heads held high and hearts open to the infinite possibilities that await. The world as we knew it is gone. But in its place, something new is being born. Something magnificent and strange and utterly beyond our former comprehension. And we are part of it. We are becoming it. We are the change. We are the transformation. We are the bridge between the world that was and the cosmos that will be. And though the journey ahead is long and the challenges immense, we face it with courage and with hope. Because we know now that we are not alone. And in the end, that is all any of us ever truly needed. To know that we are part of something greater. To know that our lives, our struggles, our very existence have meaning in the grand tapestry of creation. We are the children of Earth. And now, we are ready to become the citizens of the cosmos. The transformation is complete. And the adventure is just beginning.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter attempts to serve as the climactic finale to a cosmic horror story, presenting a collective consciousness narrative where all the previously established characters merge into a unified voice after contact with alien structures. While ambitious in concept, the execution suffers from several significant flaws. The most glaring issue is the complete abandonment of the carefully crafted individual character voices established in the profiles. Sarah Chen's Type-A control issues, Jack Thompson's poetic but grounded maritime wisdom, Elena Martinez's scientific precision, Liam O'Connor's anxious teenage perspective, Reverend Hayes' theological struggles, and Dr. Nakamura's academic awkwardness all vanish into a homogenized, pseudo-mystical voice that could belong to anyone. The brief character attributions ("Liam speaks first," "Elena adds") feel perfunctory and don't reflect their established personalities or speech patterns. The prose is heavily laden with purple language and forced mysticism. Phrases like "the slow, inexorable unraveling of reality itself," "the vast expanse of our new existence," and "the symphony of the cosmos" pile up without earning their weight. The writing relies heavily on abstract concepts (transformation, becoming, awareness) without grounding them in concrete imagery or genuine emotion. The invented alien names "Chorzhak" and "Ub-Xiath" feel arbitrary and don't add meaningful otherworldliness. The chapter does follow its stated plan of presenting a "fragmented, stream-of-consciousness account from multiple characters" and provides "an ambiguous ending," but it fails to deliver the promised exploration of how each character's unique perspective adds "new layers of mystery and dread." Instead, all characters speak with the same elevated, mystical tone that lacks the individual psychological depth the story was built upon. The transformation from cosmic horror to transcendent acceptance feels unearned. The story was established as focusing on "cosmic dread" and "the gradual breakdown of the characters' understanding of reality," but this chapter pivots to celebration and wonder without adequately bridging that emotional journey. The horror elements are abandoned in favor of New Age spirituality. The dialogue, when attributed to specific characters, doesn't match their established voices. Jack Thompson, described as having a "stoic exterior" who "speaks in tongues" about the sea's tricks, suddenly speaks in cosmic platitudes. Elena Martinez, the precise scientist, abandons her analytical nature for mystical pronouncements about wombs and seeds. The chapter does maintain coherence in its basic premise and follows the writing prompt's requirement for alien contact and communication, but it sacrifices the story's established tone and character development for abstract philosophical musings that feel more like a treatise on cosmic consciousness than a satisfying narrative conclusion. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 3 Emotionally Engaging: 6 Compelling Plot: 8 Coherent: 12 Weak Dialogue: 15 Tell-Don't-Show: 16 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 14 Purple Prose: 17 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 18 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 4 Characters Consistent with Profile: 2 Followed Chapter Plan: 11 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 13

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is an ambitious multi-chapter science fiction story that attempts to chronicle humanity's first contact with alien megastructures through multiple perspectives. The piece shows both strengths and significant weaknesses. The story's structure is well-conceived, using different viewpoint characters to build a comprehensive picture of the unfolding crisis. Each character has a distinct voice and role: Sarah the pragmatic mayor, Elena the analytical scientist, Jack the experienced fisherman, Liam the sensitive teenager, Reverend Michael questioning his faith, and Dr. Nakamura documenting the impossible. This multi-perspective approach effectively builds tension and provides varied angles on the central mystery. The world-building is solid, creating a believable small coastal town facing an incomprehensible threat. The progression from mysterious structures to dying fish to reality-warping transformations follows a logical escalation. The author demonstrates good understanding of how different community members would react to such events. However, the writing suffers from significant stylistic issues. The prose frequently veers into purple territory with overwrought metaphors and forced poetic language that doesn't enhance meaning. Phrases like "the slow, inexorable unraveling of reality itself" appear repeatedly, becoming clichéd. The dialogue often feels stilted and expository rather than natural. The pacing becomes problematic in later chapters, rushing toward a cosmic transformation that feels unearned. The final chapter's shift to a collective consciousness voice represents a dramatic tonal change that, while conceptually interesting, lacks the emotional weight it should carry. The characters' individual personalities dissolve too easily into this new state. The story's treatment of cosmic horror elements shows promise but lacks subtlety. The author tells us repeatedly that things are "incomprehensible" and "beyond understanding" rather than showing this through concrete details and character reactions. The horror becomes abstract rather than visceral. Character development is inconsistent. While each character has a clear role and voice initially, their individual arcs don't develop meaningfully before the final transformation. The teenager Liam's journal entries feel authentic, but other characters often speak in exposition rather than natural dialogue. The ending attempts profundity but feels rushed and unearned. The transformation from cosmic horror to transcendent acceptance happens too quickly, without sufficient emotional groundwork. The collective voice chapter, while stylistically ambitious, lacks the individual humanity that made the earlier chapters engaging. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 12 Pacing: 11 World Building: 15 Compelling Plot: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 13 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 14 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 11 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Unearned Transformations: 9 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17
Avg Final Item Score: 54.4/100
+ Darkly Comic British YA Fiction — Midnight Blood (Chapter Avg: 47.3 | Final: 55.1)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Darkly Comic British YA Fiction Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: The text came just after midnight: 🩸🩸🩸
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Darkly Comic British YA Fiction Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: The text came just after midnight: 🩸🩸🩸 -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming Possible characters: - A lonely teenager who receives the mysterious text - A group of rebellious friends planning something dangerous - A ghost or supernatural entity communicating through the texts - An estranged family member sending coded messages - A secret society recruiting new members Possible plot directions: - The texts are invitations to an underground fight club - The texts are warnings about a supernatural threat - The texts are part of an elaborate ARG (alternate reality game) - The texts are clues to a treasure hunt or mystery - The texts are from a future version of the protagonist Tone considerations: - Dark humor mixed with genuine suspense - Sarcastic teen voice - Satirical take on social media and texting culture - Gothic horror elements with modern twist - Absurdist comedy Story beats to consider: - Initial confusion and curiosity about the texts - Attempts to trace the source of the messages - Escalation of stakes as more texts arrive - Revelation of the true meaning behind the symbols - Climactic confrontation or decision point Pacing ideas: - Start slow with mundane teen life, then accelerate - Parallel storylines converging through the texts - Flashbacks revealing character motivations - Cliffhanger endings for most chapters - Intermittent humor to break tension # Reflection The most compelling direction seems to be a supernatural mystery with dark humor. The 🩸🩸🩸 emoji is inherently creepy but also absurd, which lends itself well to a darkly comic tone. A lonely teenager as the protagonist could work well - their isolation making them both vulnerable to whatever is behind the texts and relatable to YA readers. The ARG angle could be interesting but might feel too similar to existing YA novels. A secret society could work but might require too much world-building for a short story. The fight club idea is intriguing but the 🩸🩸🩸 emoji feels more supernatural than that. I'm leaning toward the ghost/supernatural entity idea, but with a twist - perhaps the entity is using the texts to try to prevent a tragedy rather than cause one. This could allow for both genuinely creepy moments and opportunities for dark humor as the protagonist tries to decipher increasingly bizarre messages. The 1000 words per chapter constraint means each chapter needs to accomplish a lot. Perhaps: Chapter 1: Establish protagonist and receive first text Chapter 2: Try to ignore it, but curiosity wins out Chapter 3: Begin investigating the source Chapter 4: Strange events begin occurring Chapter 5: Discover the true nature of the messages Chapter 6: Race against time to prevent disaster Chapter 7: Climax and confrontation Chapter 8: Resolution with a final twist This pacing allows for gradual escalation while leaving room for character development and the darkly comic tone. The emoji could be revealed to represent something unexpected but logical in hindsight, providing a satisfying payoff.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention I intend to write a darkly comic YA short story about a lonely teenage protagonist who receives mysterious texts containing only blood drop emojis. The story will blend supernatural mystery with sardonic humor, exploring themes of isolation, the desire for connection, and the unexpected ways help can arrive. The protagonist will be a sarcastic, intelligent loner who initially dismisses the texts as a prank but gradually realizes they're connected to strange occurrences around them. The emoji will be revealed to represent not violence, but a supernatural entity's attempts to communicate through the only medium available to it. The voice will be first-person, contemporary teen, balancing witty observations with genuine emotional depth. The humor will be dark but not mean-spirited, with the protagonist's isolation providing both vulnerability and a sharp, self-aware perspective. I aim to create genuine suspense and creepiness while maintaining an undercurrent of absurdity. The pacing will accelerate as the story progresses, with each chapter ending on a revelation or cliffhanger. I'll avoid graphic violence, instead focusing on psychological tension and the eerie nature of the texts. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: Introduce 16-year-old Alex, a sarcastic loner who receives the first 🩸🩸🩸 text. Dismiss it as a wrong number, but can't shake the feeling of being watched. Chapter 2: More texts arrive. Alex tries to trace the number, discovering it's from a phone that shouldn't exist. Strange occurrences begin - shadows moving on their own, whispers when alone. Chapter 3: Alex confides in their one friend, Sam, who suggests it might be a ghost. Alex scoffs but secretly researches local ghost stories. A new text: 🩸🩸🩸👀 Chapter 4: The entity seems to be watching Alex. Objects move in their room. A text arrives with an address. Against their better judgment, Alex goes to investigate. Chapter 5: At the address, Alex finds an abandoned house. Inside, they discover old newspaper clippings about a missing child from decades ago. The texts become more frequent and desperate. Chapter 6: Alex realizes the entity is trying to communicate through emojis, having no other way to speak. They begin deciphering the messages, learning of a tragedy about to occur. Chapter 7: The final text arrives: 🩸🩸🩸⏰🏠. Alex races to prevent the tragedy, using the ghost's cryptic clues. They confront their own fears of connection and helping others. Chapter 8: The crisis is averted, but at a cost. Alex gains a new perspective on isolation and connection. The final text: 🩸🩸🩸👋, leaving Alex to wonder if it was real or imagined.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# Human Approach Analysis A human writer might approach this piece by drawing from personal experiences of isolation, the uncanny nature of modern communication, and the blend of humor and horror that comes from life's absurdities. They might focus more on the raw, messy emotions of being a teenager - the confusion, the desperate need for connection, the way small things can feel world-ending. Humans tend to write with more inconsistency and imperfection, which can actually make characters feel more real. A human might give Alex moments of genuine fear mixed with inappropriate humor, or have them act against their own best interests in ways that feel authentic to teen behavior rather than plot-driven. Typical LLM pitfalls to avoid: 1. Overly neat plot structure: Humans often write stories that meander or have loose ends 2. Consistent tone: Real writing has tonal shifts based on the writer's mood/energy 3. Perfect character consistency: Humans are inconsistent in their behaviors and thoughts 4. Clean resolutions: Life doesn't wrap up with a bow, and neither do human-written stories 5. Optimized prose: Humans write with more repetition, awkward phrasing, and personal quirks # Critique of Current Plan The current plan is well-structured but feels a bit too neat and predictable. The emoji reveal (ghost trying to communicate) is clever but perhaps too tidy. The progression from skepticism to belief is logical but might lack the messy uncertainty a human would bring. The character of Alex is sketched out but risks being a collection of YA protagonist traits rather than a fully realized person. The voice described ("sarcastic, intelligent loner") is a common archetype that needs more specific, unique details to feel real. The dark humor is mentioned but not really explored in terms of what makes this particular character's humor unique. What are Alex's specific obsessions, fears, or experiences that shape their worldview? The pacing is efficient but might benefit from more breathing room - moments where nothing "happens" but character is revealed. The plan risks being all plot and no texture. # Brainstorming for More Human Elements Character depth: - Give Alex a specific, weird hobby or obsession that has nothing to do with the plot - Create a more complex relationship with Sam - maybe they're reconnecting after a falling out - Show Alex's loneliness through specific, concrete details rather than stating it - Give Alex moments of genuine vulnerability that aren't immediately covered by sarcasm Tone and style: - Allow for more tonal shifts - moments of genuine terror followed by absurd humor - Include Alex's internal monologue being self-contradictory or hypocritical - Use more fragmented, realistic teen dialogue rather than polished wit - Incorporate modern communication elements (drafts, unsent messages, misread tones) Plot messiness: - Have Alex misinterpret the messages in ways that create genuine setbacks - Include a subplot that doesn't directly relate to the main mystery but reveals character - Allow for moments where Alex simply fails or gives up - Create ambiguity about whether the supernatural elements are real Specific details: - What's the exact content of Alex's room? What posters, items, mess reveals who they are? - What's a specific, weird memory from Alex's past that shapes how they see the world? - What's a mundane frustration Alex deals with that has nothing to do with the plot? - What's a specific way Alex fails at being a good friend or person, revealed through action? These elements would make the story feel less like a well-crafted narrative and more like a real person's experience - messy, contradictory, and alive.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention I intend to write a darkly comic YA short story that captures the messy, contradictory experience of being a lonely teenager in the modern world. The story will use the mysterious 🩸🩸🩸 texts as a catalyst to explore Alex's isolation, their desperate need for connection, and the unexpected ways help can arrive. The voice will be first-person, contemporary teen, but with more raw imperfection than polished YA prose. Alex will be sarcastic and intelligent, but also self-contradictory, occasionally cruel, and prone to inappropriate humor even in scary situations. Their loneliness will be shown through specific details (endless hours scrolling social media, talking to their pet lizard, memorizing Wikipedia articles) rather than stated. The humor will be dark and specific to Alex's personality - perhaps they make morbid jokes about their own situation, or find absurd humor in genuinely creepy moments. The supernatural element will be treated with both genuine fear and sardonic disbelief, reflecting how a real teen might react. I aim to create a story that feels less like a crafted narrative and more like a real experience - with moments of genuine terror, inappropriate laughter, and the kind of messy emotional truth that comes from being alone and unsure. The plot will have logical progression but also include setbacks, misinterpretations, and moments where Alex simply fails. I'll avoid neat resolutions, consistent tone, and overly clever plot mechanics. Instead, I'll focus on creating a specific, weird, human character whose experience of the supernatural feels as real and messy as their experience of being a teenager. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: Alex, awake at 12:47 AM, receives the first 🩸🩸🩸 text. They're alone in their room, surrounded by the detritus of isolation (empty snack wrappers, a pet lizard in a tank, multiple devices charging). They text back "new phone who dis" and get no response. The chapter ends with Alex noticing shadows moving in their room that shouldn't be. Chapter 2: More texts arrive. Alex, sleep-deprived and jittery, tries to investigate. They discover the number is from a phone that doesn't exist. At school, they're distracted and irritable, snapping at their only friend Sam when they try to help. A text arrives with an address and 👀. Alex debates going but decides against it, then changes their mind. Chapter 3: At the address (an abandoned house), Alex finds nothing but old newspapers about a missing child. They text Sam about it, then immediately regret sharing something weird. Back home, they receive 🩸🩸🩸👀 again, making them question if they're being watched. They stay up all night researching local ghost stories. Chapter 4: Strange things escalate - Alex's shower turns ice cold, their phone autocorrects everything to "blood," they hear whispers through their headphones. They confide in Sam, who suggests it might be a ghost. Alex scoffs but secretly hopes it's true - at least a ghost would be company. A new text: 🩸🩸🩸⏰. Chapter 5: The entity seems to be counting down to something. Alex stays home "sick," obsessively checking their phone. They receive a text with a specific time and their home address. Alex panics but also feels a weird thrill - something is happening to them, at least. They decide to confront it. Chapter 6: Alex prepares for the "arrival" by setting up cameras, researching demonology, and writing a will that's mostly jokes. When nothing happens at the appointed time, they feel both relieved and disappointed. Then their little sister almost has a terrible accident, prevented only by Alex's sudden, inexplicable knowledge of what was about to happen. Chapter 7: Alex realizes the entity is trying to communicate through emojis because it has no other way. They begin deciphering the messages, learning the ghost is the spirit of the missing child, trying to prevent tragedies it couldn't stop in life. Alex feels both terrified and needed - a new, uncomfortable feeling. Chapter 8: The final text arrives: 🩸🩸🩸⏰🏥. Alex races to the hospital, using the ghost's clues to prevent a disaster. They succeed but get in trouble for being there. The story ends with Alex back in their room, receiving 🩸🩸🩸👋. They're not sure if it was real, but they text back "thanks for trying, I guess" and mean it. The last line is Alex falling asleep with their phone in hand, finally not alone.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Alex Background: 16, lives in a suburban town that's simultaneously too small and too big. Parents work a lot - mom's a nurse with night shifts, dad's a consultant who travels. Has a 10-year-old sister named Zoe who's the family favorite. Used to have a bigger friend group but drifted away sophomore year. Now spends most free time online, particularly in a Discord server about true crime and unsolved mysteries. Personality: Sharp-witted but defensive, uses sarcasm as armor. Intelligent but unmotivated in traditional academics - aces English essays but fails math tests. Has a fascination with the macabre that's equal parts genuine interest and attention-seeking. Prone to overthinking social interactions for hours afterward. Secretly desperate for connection but convinced they don't need anyone. Idiosyncracies: Counts things when anxious (steps, ceiling tiles, words in sentences). Has an extensive collection of weird facts they bring up at inappropriate times. Sleeps with their phone under their pillow. Names inanimate objects (their laptop is "Mortimer," their backpack is "Benedict"). Flaws: Pushes people away preemptively. Makes cruel jokes to mask insecurity. Procrastinates on everything until it becomes an emergency. Gets so lost in their own head they miss obvious things happening around them. Physicality: Tall and lanky, always slouching to seem shorter. Hair perpetually in their eyes because they "forget" to get it cut. Wears the same black hoodie every day until their mom steals it to wash it. Has a habit of picking at their cuticles when thinking. Eyes are slightly different sizes, which they're extremely self-conscious about. Motives: Wants to feel special, seen, important. Scared of being ordinary or forgettable. Would rather be the weird one than the invisible one. Their allegiance is ultimately to themselves, though they'd never admit it. Relationships: Strained but loving relationship with parents (they worry about Alex's isolation but don't know how to help). Adores Zoe but acts like she's annoying. Sam is their only friend, but Alex often takes them for granted. Online friends know more about Alex's real thoughts than anyone in real life. Dialogue samples: "God, I'd rather be haunted than bored. At least ghosts are trying to communicate." "I'm not lonely, I'm selectively social. It's different." "Plot twist: I'm the final girl AND the monster. I contain multitudes." # Sam Background: Also 16, has known Alex since elementary school. Their friendship survived Alex's withdrawal because Sam is stubborn and doesn't give up on people easily. Lives with a single mom and two younger siblings - often has to babysit, which is why they're sometimes unavailable. Wants to be a filmmaker and is always shooting little videos on their phone. Personality: Loyal to a fault, sometimes to their own detriment. Optimistic but not naive - they see the good in people while still being realistic about their flaws. Creative and empathetic, often the one who notices when someone's upset. Can be a bit of a people-pleaser, afraid of conflict. Idiosyncracies: Always carrying around a small notebook to jot down ideas or observations. Has a habit of narrating life like it's a movie in their head. Collects vintage cameras even though they mostly shoot digital. Makes obscure film references that no one else gets. Flaws: Avoids confrontation to the point of letting problems fester. Sometimes enables Alex's worst behaviors because they want to be supportive. Can be overbearing in their attempts to help. Takes on other people's emotions to the point of losing track of their own. Physicality: Short and compact, with a way of moving that's always busy - fidgeting, adjusting their ever-present beanie, checking their phone. Has expressive hands that never stop moving when they talk. Their smile is crooked and they have a dimple in only one cheek. Wears colorful, slightly mismatched clothes that look like they came from three different outfits. Motives: Wants to connect with people, to understand them, to help them tell their stories. Scared of being forgotten or not mattering. Their allegiance is to the people they loves, sometimes at the expense of their own needs. Relationships: Alex is their closest friend, even if Alex doesn't always act like it. Has a teasing but loving relationship with their siblings. Admires their hardworking mom but wishes they had more time together. Online, they're part of a small community of aspiring filmmakers who critique each other's work. Dialogue samples: "You know you can text me back without solving a riddle, right? I'm not grading this." "I'm filming this. Not for any reason, just because someday we'll want to remember when you were being a cryptid." "Look, I'm not saying you're haunted. I'm just saying, what if you're haunted? As a friend." # Zoe Background: 10 years old, in fifth grade. The "easy" child compared to Alex, which she both enjoys and resents. Loves animals and wants to be a vet when she grows up. Spends a lot of time at dance classes and soccer practice - the one kid activity their parents can consistently get excited about. Personality: Bubbly on the surface but with a sharp, observant streak. Knows she's the favorite and sometimes uses it to her advantage. Genuinely loves Alex but also finds their moodiness confusing and a bit scary. Brave in the way kids are before they learn to be afraid - will pick up bugs, explore dark basements, try gross food. Idiosyncracies: Collects rocks and assigns them all personalities and backstories. Has an imaginary friend named Mr. Whispers who "lives in the walls." Sings to herself constantly, usually show tunes or pop songs she's half-misremembering. Always has a pack of gum, which she offers to people as a weird olive branch. Flaws: Can be a tattletale when she feels wronged. Sometimes uses her status as the cute younger kid to get out of trouble. Doesn't always know when to leave Alex alone, even when she's clearly bothering them. Physicality: Small and quick, with the boundless energy of a kid who hasn't quite outgrown constant movement. Has wild, curly hair that's always escaping its ponytail. When she walks, she dances - a little step-touch with every other step. Her expressions are comically exaggerated; she hasn't learned to hide her feelings yet. Motives: Wants to be seen as grown-up but also desperately wants to stay a kid. Loves her family but doesn't understand why Alex seems to hate theirs. Her allegiance is simple - to fairness, to being liked, to figuring out the world. Relationships: Worships Alex in a way that's equal parts sibling love and hero worship. Has a group of friends at school but sometimes feels like the odd one out. Parents love her but are often distracted by work or Alex's issues. Mr. Whispers is her closest confidant, even if he is imaginary. Dialogue samples: "Alex, why do you look like you're plotting a murder when you're just sitting there? Are you plotting a murder?" "You can't ignore me forever. I learned that in school. It's called 'perseverance.'" "Mr. Whispers says you're sad. He also says you have Cheeto dust in your bed. I didn't ask how he knows." # The Entity Background: The ghost of a child who went missing in the 90s in Alex's town. Exact circumstances unclear - the newspaper clippings Alex finds are vague, possibly covered up. Has been "awake" and aware but unable to communicate for years. The 🩸🩸🩸 texts are their attempt to reach out through the only medium available to them. Personality: Childlike but not childish - had an old soul even before they died. Determined and stubborn, refused to "move on" until they could prevent what happened to them from happening to others. Frustrated by their inability to communicate clearly. Has a dry, dark sense of humor that developed from years of isolation. Idiosyncracies: Communicates almost entirely in emojis and short, broken text messages. Has an encyclopedic knowledge of local history and current events. Sometimes sends Alex random, outdated pop culture references. Leaves small, inexplicable signs (cold spots, moved objects) that are more annoying than scary. Flaws: Single-minded to the point of tunnel vision. Sometimes causes more problems than they solve with their attempts to help. Can be manipulative in pursuit of their goals. Doesn't always understand how the modern world works. Physicality: Non-corporeal, but when Alex "sees" them (which isn't always clear if it's real or imagined), they appear as a child around 10-12, wearing 90s clothes that are slightly out of fashion. Their face is often obscured or shifting. They move in a way that's both childlike and unsettlingly weightless. Motives: To prevent the tragedy they couldn't stop in life. To be heard, understood, maybe even forgiven. Their allegiance is to the living children they're trying to protect, even if it means using Alex. Relationships: Their only relationship is with Alex, which is complicated by the fact that they're using Alex for their own ends. They feel a kinship with Alex's loneliness but also frustration at their hesitation. There's no family left to miss them, which is part of why they're still here. Dialogue samples: "WATCH. 11:03. HOUSE. 🩸🩸🩸" "YOU'RE NOT CRAZY. OR MAYBE YOU ARE. DOESN'T MATTER." "THE DARKNESS LISTENS. THE DARKNESS REMEMBERS. THE DARKNESS WANTS." "I USED TO COLLECT STICKERS. DID YOU KNOW THAT? BEFORE. 🩸🩸🩸" # Character 1: Alex <character exploration> # Character 2: Sam <character exploration> # Character 3: Zoe <character exploration> # Character 4: The Entity <character exploration>

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 1 The text came just after midnight: 🩸🩸🩸 I was sprawled on my bed, laptop warming my legs, scrolling through a true crime forum about unsolved disappearances in my town. The glow of the screen lit up my room in a way that was probably terrible for my sleep schedule but perfect for late-night paranoia. My phone buzzed on the pillow next to me, and I didn't even look at it before typing back "new phone who dis" and hitting send. The thing is, I don't get texts. Not really. My parents text me grocery lists and reminders about Zoe's dance recitals. Sam texts me memes that I usually forget to open for three days. That's it. So when my phone buzzed again with the same three blood drop emojis, I actually sat up and paid attention. I counted the emojis. Three. Definitely not a mistake or an autocorrect fail. Someone had deliberately sent me three blood drop emojis at 12:47 AM. My first thought was spam, but spammers usually try to sell you something or threaten to kill your family if you don't send bitcoin. This was just... blood drops. My lizard, Godzilla, looked at me from his tank. His eyes reflected the light weirdly, making him look like a tiny dragon. "This is fine," I told him. "Probably just a wrong number." I waited thirty seconds. No response. I opened the message again. Still just the blood drops. I took a screenshot and posted it to my Discord server: "Guys, am I being ghosted by a vampire emoji?" The responses came fast: - "Delete that immediately" - "It's a glitch, happens all the time" - "Bro are you okay?" - "I'm calling the police" I laughed and closed Discord. It was definitely a glitch or a wrong number. Nothing to worry about. I was just sleep-deprived and paranoid from reading about missing kids. Totally normal. I turned off my laptop and phone, letting my room settle into darkness. The streetlight outside cast an orange glow through my curtains, making everything look jaundiced and strange. I closed my eyes and tried to sleep. That's when I heard it. Not a sound, exactly. More like a shift in the silence. The kind of quiet that feels heavy, like the air itself is listening. I opened my eyes and stared at the ceiling. My room looked normal - desk covered in empty soda cans, laundry spilling out of my hamper, posters of old horror movies peeling at the corners. Everything where it should be. But something was watching me. I sat up slowly, scanning the shadows. My closet door was open a crack, just like I'd left it. My curtains fluttered slightly, though I couldn't feel any breeze. Nothing seemed out of place, but the feeling persisted - that prickling awareness of being observed. "Godzilla, if this is you trying to get me to clean your tank, it's working," I said, trying to sound normal. Godzilla blinked slowly from his heat lamp, unimpressed. I got out of bed and checked the lock on my door. Secure. I peered into the hallway - dark, silent, nothing unusual. Back in my room, I opened my closet, expecting maybe a draft or a weird reflection. Just clothes and shoes and the growing pile of things I'd procrastinated putting away. The bathroom across the hall was the same - dark, quiet, slightly gross. I flicked on the light and checked behind the shower curtain, because apparently I'd decided to become the protagonist in a bad horror movie. Nothing but my sister's collection of plastic dinosaurs and the lingering smell of whatever bath bomb Zoe had used earlier. I splashed some water on my face and looked at myself in the mirror. My hair was a mess, my eyes were bloodshot from staring at screens, and I had a mysterious stain on my shirt that might have been chocolate or might have been something worse. I looked like someone who was definitely not about to be contacted by the supernatural. When I got back to my room, my phone was lit up on my pillow. A new message: 🩸🩸🩸👀 I froze. The cursor on my phone screen blinked patiently, waiting for me to respond. I wanted to type something sarcastic, something that would prove I wasn't scared, but my fingers wouldn't cooperate. Instead, I just stared at those four characters - three blood drops and an eye - until they started to blur together. Something moved in my peripheral vision. I whipped my head toward the window, toward the closet, toward the corner where my laundry basket sat. Nothing. Just my room, just the familiar shadows and shapes I saw every night. My phone buzzed again. A new message: 🩸🩸🩸📍 A location pin. Attached to a map that showed an address I didn't recognize. Somewhere on the other side of town, in the older part with the big Victorian houses that people said were haunted. I wanted to text back "fuck off," but instead I found myself typing "who is this" and hitting send before I could second-guess myself. No response. Of course no response. Why would there be a response? I was having a breakdown over spam texts, that's all. I was sleep-deprived and stressed about finals and reading too many scary stories online. I turned my phone off completely and plugged it in across the room, following the sleep hygiene advice I never actually used. I crawled back into bed and pulled the covers over my head like I was five years old again, hiding from monsters in the closet. The thing is, when you're a teenager, you're supposed to be too old for monsters. You're supposed to trade them in for real fears - failing classes, losing friends, disappointing your parents. You're supposed to be cynical and world-weary, too smart to believe in anything you can't see or measure or post about on social media. But lying there in the dark, with my heart pounding and my skin crawling with the certainty that something was very wrong, I realized that maybe I'd never stopped believing in monsters. Maybe I'd just been waiting for one to notice me.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter establishes a strong foundation for the darkly comic British YA story, successfully capturing the voice and perspective of Alex as outlined in the character profile. The writing demonstrates solid technical competence and creates an engaging opening that balances supernatural mystery with authentic teenage voice. The characterization of Alex is particularly well-executed. The narrator's voice feels genuinely teenage - self-deprecating, sarcastic, and defensive, with moments of vulnerability breaking through the cynical exterior. Lines like "I looked like someone who was definitely not about to be contacted by the supernatural" and the interaction with Godzilla the lizard effectively establish Alex's personality while maintaining the darkly comic tone. The character's isolation is shown through specific details (scrolling true crime forums alone at midnight, having minimal text contacts) rather than simply stated. The supernatural element is introduced effectively through the mysterious emoji texts. The progression from dismissive humor ("new phone who dis") to growing unease feels natural and maintains reader engagement. The use of emojis as the primary communication method is creative and fits well with modern YA sensibilities while creating an appropriately unsettling atmosphere. The writing successfully follows the chapter plan, introducing Alex in their isolated state, establishing the mysterious texts, and ending with the sense of being watched. The pacing builds tension appropriately, moving from casual dismissal to genuine concern. However, there are some areas where the writing could be stronger. The prose occasionally veers toward overwrought description, particularly in passages like "The kind of quiet that feels heavy, like the air itself is listening." While atmospheric, such moments risk feeling forced rather than organic to Alex's voice. The ending, while effective in building tension, relies somewhat on familiar horror tropes (checking closets, bathroom mirrors, things moving in peripheral vision) that feel predictable. The dialogue, while limited, feels authentic to the character. Alex's interactions with their lizard and the Discord responses capture appropriate teenage communication patterns. The internal monologue maintains consistency throughout and effectively conveys Alex's psychological state. The chapter successfully establishes the tone requested in the prompt - darkly comic British YA - though the British elements are subtle. The humor emerges naturally from Alex's personality rather than feeling forced, and the dark elements build appropriately without overwhelming the narrative. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 2 I woke up to my phone buzzing incessantly on the other side of the room. The morning sun was already streaming through my curtains, casting stripes of light across my floor. I'd forgotten to close them completely, a rookie mistake when you're trying to sleep past seven. My head hurt. Not a hangover headache - I didn't drink - but the kind of dull, thudding pain that comes from sleeping poorly and probably grinding your teeth. I'd had that weird, shallow sleep where you keep thinking you're falling and jerk yourself awake, except in my case I kept thinking I saw shadows moving in my room. The buzzing continued. I rolled over and glared at my phone, trying to remember if I'd actually turned it off last night or just imagined doing it. The screen was lit up with notifications - texts, emails, Discord mentions. Someone was trying very hard to get my attention. I dragged myself out of bed and shuffled over to where my phone sat, still plugged into the charger. The battery was at 100%, which meant I had definitely turned it off. Which meant something - or someone - had turned it back on. The notification panel showed a series of messages from the same unknown number: 🩸🩸🩸 🩸🩸🩸 🩸🩸🩸 🩸🩸🩸 🩸🩸🩸 And so on, for about thirty messages. I opened the conversation. The texts started at 1:23 AM and continued until 3:47 AM, when my phone had finally died or been turned off. Each message was just the three blood drop emojis, sent in rapid succession like someone was hammering on a keyboard with one finger. My hands were shaking slightly as I scrolled through them. Not because I was scared - I wasn't scared. I was tired and annoyed and maybe a little bit curious, but definitely not scared. This was just someone's idea of a joke, or a wrong number that had gotten stuck in a loop. I typed back: "If this is a robot, you're not very good at it. If this is a person, you need a hobby." No response. Of course no response. I was talking to a glitch or a spam bot or some kid who'd entered the wrong number and was now too embarrassed to admit it. I went to the bathroom, peed, washed my face, and tried to look like someone who hadn't spent half the night convinced their room was haunted. The mirror didn't lie - I looked like I'd slept in a haunted room. My eyes were bloodshot, my hair was sticking up in eleven different directions, and I had pillow creases on one cheek that made me look like I'd been in a fight with my bedding. Back in my room, I pulled up the details on the mystery number. It wasn't saved in my contacts, which meant it wasn't anyone I knew. The number itself was weird - no area code, just ten digits that started with 555. I frowned at that. 555 was the prefix they used in movies for fake phone numbers. But this wasn't a movie, and my phone was definitely receiving these texts. I googled the number. Nothing. No reports of spam, no mentions of mysterious texts, no indication that 555 was even a valid prefix in our area code. I tried calling it from my laptop using one of those free internet phone services. It rang once, twice, three times, then disconnected with a message saying the number was not in service. Okay. So the number didn't exist. Which meant either my phone was haunted or I was losing my mind. Both options seemed equally plausible at this point. I heard my mom moving around downstairs, probably making coffee and trying to pretend she didn't have to go to work in an hour. The smell of burnt toast drifted up the stairs - Zoe's attempt at making breakfast, no doubt. I could hear her singing to herself, some pop song where she only knew every third word. My phone buzzed. A new message from the mystery number: 🩸🩸🩸📱 I stared at it. Three blood drops and a phone. Was it asking for a call back? Telling me to look at my phone? Congratulating me on figuring out it was a phone doing the texting? I typed back: "What do you want?" The response was immediate: 🩸🩸🩸📍 Another location pin. The same address as last night. I opened it on my laptop, pulling it up on Google Maps. It was a house in the historic district, one of those big old Victorians with turrets and wraparound porches. The street view showed it covered in scaffolding, probably being renovated. The listing said it was built in 1892 and had "tons of original character, needs some TLC." I googled the address plus "haunted." Because of course I did. And of course it came up - local ghost forums, a few YouTube videos, an article from the town paper about "the mystery of Montague Manor." Apparently, it was the site of multiple disappearances over the years, the most recent being a kid who'd gone missing in the 90s and was never found. I closed the tab. This was ridiculous. I wasn't going to some supposedly haunted house just because a spam bot sent me a map. I had a calculus test to study for and a group project where I was pretty sure I was doing all the work. I didn't have time to investigate ghost stories. My phone buzzed again: 🩸🩸🩸⏰ A stopwatch emoji. Counting down to something. Counting down to me doing what, exactly? Driving across town to a house that was probably condemned? Knocking on the door and asking if any ghosts needed tech support? I wanted to throw my phone across the room. Instead, I screenshotted the conversation so far and sent it to Sam with the caption "should I be scared or just throw my phone in the river." Sam responded almost immediately: "Both. Definitely both. Also, what the actual fuck." "I know," I typed back. "It's just spam, right?" "It's definitely spam," Sam wrote. "But also, maybe don't go to that house? Just a thought." "Too late," I typed, even though I hadn't decided anything yet. "I'm already investigating." I could almost hear Sam sighing through the text. "Of course you are. You and your stupid curiosity. Just please, please don't get murdered by a glitch." I laughed, even though nothing about the situation was funny. Sam was the only person who really got me - my stupid need to poke at things until they either explained themselves or bit back. They'd been there when I'd stayed up all night trying to find the source of a weird humming noise in my house (it was the water heater, and I'd gotten grounded for "tampering with utilities"). They'd helped me break into the school's theater after hours to investigate rumors of a ghost (it was just a homeless person, and I'd gotten detention for "trespassing and being a general pain in the ass"). This was just the next chapter in the ongoing saga of Alex Jordan Can't Leave Well Enough Alone. I was going to text back, go to that house, and probably find out it was all just a stupid misunderstanding. And if it wasn't? If it was actually something weird? Well, that would be a story worth telling. I typed back to the mystery number: "Fine. I'll bite. What's at the house?" The response came instantly: 🩸🩸🩸👀 Three blood drops and an eye. Watching. Waiting. Wanting me to do something stupid, probably. I grabbed my backpack, threw in my laptop, a notebook, and three different kinds of snacks (priorities), and headed for the door. I texted my mom that I was going to the library to study, which was technically true - if I found anything interesting at the house, I'd definitely be studying it. As I was heading down the stairs, Zoe popped her head out of the kitchen. "Where are you going?" she asked, strawberry jam on her cheek. "Library," I said, grabbing an apple from the bowl on the counter. "At eleven in the morning? On a Saturday?" She raised an eyebrow in a way that was way too accurate for a ten-year-old. "I have a big project," I said, already backing toward the door. She took a bite of her toast, chewing thoughtfully. "You know, Mr. Whispers says you're going somewhere you shouldn't." "Mr. Whispers can mind his own business," I said, but my hand paused on the doorknob. Mr. Whispers was Zoe's imaginary friend, a habit she should have outgrown two years ago but insisted was real.
